s.text: Law school graduates paying back $80,000 and more in college loans are reluctant to seek low-paying jobs representing the poor, legal experts say.
Law school graduates paying back $80,000 and more in college loans are reluctant to seek low-paying jobs representing the poor, legal experts say.

Students leaving law schools earn annual salaries as low as $25,000 working for government public-service organizations, while those who land jobs with top-ranked law firms make $80,000 a year or more.
When she was still in high school, she decided she wanted to be a lawyer and work with the poor.
So far, Asher said, Colorado Legal Services has been able to attract the talent it needs.
